Comment: I support parental leave of course, however I must point out that these policies haven't led to increased fertility rates, with Estonia's for example currently sitting close to that of the U.S.  I think that this is a much more deeply rooted systemic problem.   First I ask, who chooses to bring new people into a world where people simply aren't valued?   There's also a market squeeze phenomenon going on right now that I'm not sure people have caught onto yet. Companies with access to big data know how much you can manage to scrounge and pay for something. Prices adjust far more quickly than they did a generation ago.   Fewer people having kids, especially when they're young, gives leeway for companies/markets to raise prices since those people don't have to deal with childcare costs that were the norm a generation ago. By the time they're a bit older and actually ready to have children, the markets have decided they can afford to pay more for transport/housing/insurance/commodities and they're effectively priced out of parenthood by market forces.
